question: Show that the function $f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$, given by $f(1) = f(2) = 1$ and $f(x) = x - 1$, for every $x > 2$, is onto but not one-one.
solution:
$f$ is not one-one, as $f(1) = f(2) = 1$. 

But $f$ is onto, as given any $y \in \mathbb{N}, y \neq 1$, we can choose $x$ as $y + 1$ such that $f(y + 1) = y + 1 - 1 = y$. 

Also for $1 \in \mathbb{N}$, we have $f(1) = 1$.
